program_name: Xcel Energy Texas Saver's Switch Program
description: Xcel Energy's Saver's Switch program in Texas helps manage peak electricity demand by remotely cycling central air conditioning units and electric water heaters during high-demand periods. The program operates through Southwestern Public Service Company (SPS) in the Texas Panhandle region. Participants receive annual credits for allowing remote control of their AC units during peak demand events, which typically occur on hot summer days between 2 PM and 7 PM. The program uses a remote switch that cycles AC units on and off for 15-20 minute intervals, while the fan continues to circulate air.

service_territories: Lubbock area (note: Lubbock Power & Light has since moved to ERCOT)
geography.critical_geography_note: IMPORTANT: Xcel Energy's Texas service territory (Southwestern Public Service Company) is part of the Southwest Power Pool (SPP) grid, NOT ERCOT. The Texas Panhandle joined SPP in 1978 and remains outside ERCOT jurisdiction. This program does NOT integrate with ERCOT demand response mechanisms.

customer_classes.size_threshold_notes: Program is designed for residential customers with central air conditioning. Apartment and condo residents are eligible only with owner approval and ground-level dedicated AC units. Not applicable to rooftop ACs, window units, or wall units.

additional_requirements: Must be an Xcel Energy customer in participating service areas
Must have central air conditioning installed
For apartments/condos: ground-level dedicated AC unit required
Cannot be rooftop AC, window unit, or wall unit
Remote-controlled switch must be installed by Xcel Energy

notice_details.advance_notice_provided: No specific advance notice documented - program operates via automated switch activation
notice_details.notification_to_customer: Customers typically 'don't even notice' when system is activated according to program materials

seasonal_rates.notes: Participants save $10 on their June through September electric energy charges each year they participate. Credit applied to October electric bill.

capacity_rate.payment_timing: Annual credit applied to October electric bill

performance_rate.notes: No performance-based payment. All compensation is a flat annual credit for program participation.

penalty_structure.penalty_description: No penalties documented for non-performance or override of switch.

bonus_payments.description: Additional payment for electric water heater enrollment
bonus_payments.conditions: Available if customer enrolls a qualifying electric water heater in addition to AC unit. Water heater will shut off usually for 4-6 hours during hot summer days or cold winter afternoons. Stored hot water remains available during shutdown period.

payment_caps.notes: Base payment: $10 annual credit (June-September period, paid in October). Optional water heater addition: $2/month year-round ($24 annually). Maximum combined: $34/year if both AC and water heater enrolled.

seasons.notes: Primary season for AC cycling events. Based on recent years (2019-2024), events occurred only once per year during this period, lasting 2-4 hours. Typical activation window is 2 PM to 7 PM on hot summer days.
Water heaters may be controlled during cold winter afternoons if enrolled. AC units are not cycled during winter months.

call_windows.notes: Saver's Switch is typically activated between 2 PM and 7 PM on control days. AC units cycle on and off for 15-20 minute intervals while fan continues circulating air.

cycling_specifications.fan_operation: Fan stays on continuously during cycling to circulate pre-cooled air

historical_frequency.source: Regulatory news from 2024 indicates program was activated just once per year during the past five years

maximum_control_hours.notes: Maximum allowable control hours per year. However, actual usage is typically a small fraction of this maximum. Recent history shows only 2-4 hours used per year (single annual event).

event_parameters.customer_impact: Most customers 'don't even notice' the system's activation according to program marketing materials

enrollment_period.notes: Rolling enrollment available. Customers can enroll at any time through poweredbyefi.org website or by contacting Xcel Energy.

enrollment_process: Technician installs remote-controlled switch on AC unit and/or water heater

performance_measurement.notes: This is a traditional direct load control program. Customers receive flat annual payment for allowing control, regardless of actual load reduction achieved. No individual metering or performance measurement.

multi_state_participation.program_consistency: Program operates across multiple Xcel Energy service territories with similar structure but state-specific regulatory frameworks

grid_operator_integration.spp_coordination: Xcel Energy coordinates load management with SPP regional transmission organization
grid_operator_integration.critical_note: This program does NOT participate in ERCOT markets or ERCOT demand response programs. Texas Panhandle is part of SPP, not ERCOT.

program_evolution.change_description: Program launched with traditional Saver's Switch hardware
Regulatory review in some jurisdictions regarding cycling ratios. South Dakota regulators drew limits on switch usage.

program_history.enrollment_note: 320,000 business and residential customers enrolled across all Xcel Energy service territories (Minnesota, Colorado, Texas, New Mexico, and other states)

program_operations.control_mechanism: Remote-controlled hardware switch installed on AC unit and/or water heater
program_operations.cycling_method: Automated cycling of compressor (15-20 min intervals) while fan continues operating
program_operations.customer_comfort: Program designed to minimize customer discomfort - fan continues circulating pre-cooled air, most customers don't notice activation
program_operations.installation: Professional installation by Xcel Energy technician at no cost to customer

integration_metadata.notes: CRITICAL LIMITATION: This program operates in SPP territory, NOT ERCOT. It cannot be integrated with ERCOT battery optimization strategies. Program is traditional direct load control with flat annual payments, not event-based market participation. Limited optimization value due to: (1) non-ERCOT territory, (2) residential-only program with small payments ($10-34/year), (3) automated switch control with no customer dispatch flexibility, (4) extremely low event frequency (1 event/year historically), (5) no performance-based payments or price signals.
optimization_considerations: NOT APPLICABLE TO ERCOT BATTERY OPTIMIZATION - Program is in SPP territory
Residential program only - not suitable for commercial battery systems
No dispatch flexibility - automated switch control only
Payment is flat annual credit, not performance-based
Extremely low event frequency (1 event per year in recent history)
Total annual payment only $10-34 per household
No real-time price signals or market integration
Hardware switch controls load directly - no customer decision-making
Program designed for traditional residential AC load, not batteries
integration_metadata.ercot_relevance: NONE - This program operates in Southwest Power Pool (SPP) territory in the Texas Panhandle, completely separate from ERCOT jurisdiction. It has no integration with ERCOT markets, ERCOT demand response programs, or ERCOT price signals.
integration_metadata.battery_applicability: Not applicable. This is a traditional residential direct load control program for AC units and water heaters with hardware switch installation. It does not support behind-the-meter battery participation and provides no economic optimization opportunities for battery storage systems.

clarifications.spp_not_ercot: CRITICAL: Xcel Energy's Texas service territory (Southwestern Public Service Company) operates in the Southwest Power Pool (SPP) regional transmission organization, NOT in ERCOT. The Texas Panhandle joined SPP in 1978 and remains outside ERCOT's jurisdiction. This means the program has NO integration with ERCOT markets, ERCOT demand response programs, or ERCOT operational mechanisms.
clarifications.lubbock_exception: Lubbock Power & Light (municipal utility) historically was part of SPP but has since built 150 miles of transmission lines to connect to ERCOT. However, Xcel Energy/SPS territory in the Panhandle remains in SPP.
clarifications.payment_structure: This is a simple capacity payment program structured as a flat annual credit. Customers receive $10 for June-September participation (paid in October) regardless of actual load reduction or number of events. Optional $2/month year-round for water heater enrollment. No performance-based payments.
clarifications.event_frequency: Despite program rules allowing up to 300 hours of control per year, actual usage has been minimal. Regulatory reporting from 2024 indicates only 1 event per year during 2019-2024 period, lasting 2-4 hours each. This is substantially lower than the theoretical maximum.
clarifications.residential_only: Program is designed exclusively for residential customers with central AC and electric water heaters. Not applicable to commercial or industrial customers. Separate business programs may exist but were not found in research.
clarifications.hardware_requirement: Unlike modern smart thermostat programs, this program requires physical installation of a remote-controlled switch by Xcel Energy technicians. This is traditional direct load control technology.
clarifications.customer_experience: Program marketing emphasizes that 'most customers don't even notice' when the switch is activated because the fan continues running and cycling occurs in short 15-20 minute intervals.
clarifications.multi_state_program: Saver's Switch operates across multiple Xcel Energy service territories including Minnesota, Colorado, Texas, New Mexico, and others. Total enrollment across all states is approximately 320,000 customers. Program structure is similar across states but specific payments and regulations vary by jurisdiction.

research_notes.critical_limitation_for_ercot_battery_op: THIS PROGRAM IS NOT RELEVANT FOR ERCOT BATTERY OPTIMIZATION. It operates in SPP territory (Texas Panhandle), not ERCOT territory. It is a residential direct load control program with flat annual payments ($10-34/year), not a market-based demand response program suitable for commercial battery storage optimization. The program has no integration with ERCOT markets, prices, or operational systems.
